p: Worldwide, wild and domestic ruminants, as a result of metabolic processes (enteric fermentation), produce 15% â€“ 25% of total methane gas emissions, 74% of which is caused by cattle (Tamminga 1996). Enteric fermentation generates approximately 86 million tonnes of CH 4 worldwide (Steinfeld et al. 2006). Managing methane emissions from ruminants in general, and dairy cattle feeding strategies in particular, is important in climate change mitigation (Volenzo 2015). Mitigating greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions requires comprehensive action by policymakers, producers and consumers (Koneswaran & Nierenberg 2008).
